1f:Td04,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Milanesa Napolitana","description":"Argentina's ultimate comfort food—a breaded beef cutlet topped with ham, tomato sauce, and melted mozzarella. A perfect hybrid of Italian and Argentine cuisine that appears on every neighborhood menu.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/milanesa.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT20M","cookTime":"PT15M","totalTime":"PT35M","recipeYield":"4 servings","recipeCategory":"main","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"milanesa napolitana recipe, argentine milanesa, authentic milanesa, breaded beef cutlet, milanesa argentina","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"580 calories","proteinContent":"42g","carbohydrateContent":"35g","fatContent":"34g"},"recipeIngredient":["For the milanesa: 4 thin beef cutlets (top round or sirloin), pounded to 1/4 inch thick","For the milanesa: 1 cup all-purpose flour","For the milanesa: 2 eggs, beaten","For the milanesa: 2 cups breadcrumbs (panko for extra crispy, or fine Argentine miga de pan)","For the milanesa: 1 tsp garlic powder","For the milanesa: 1 tsp dried oregano","For the milanesa: Salt and black pepper","For the milanesa: Vegetable oil for frying (enough for 1/2 inch in pan)","For the Napolitana topping: 1 cup tomato sauce (salsa de tomate)","For the Napolitana topping: 4 slices cooked ham","For the Napolitana topping: 8 slices mozzarella cheese","For the Napolitana topping: 1 tsp dried oregano","For the Napolitana topping: Grated Parmesan cheese (optional)"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Pound the beef cutlets between plastic wrap until uniformly thin (1/4 inch). Season both sides with salt, pepper, and garlic powder."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"Set up your breading station: flour on one plate, beaten eggs in a shallow bowl, breadcrumbs mixed with oregano on another plate."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"Dredge each cutlet in flour, shaking off excess. Dip in egg, letting excess drip off. Press into breadcrumbs, coating both sides firmly."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Place breaded cutlets on a wire rack and refrigerate for 15 minutes. This helps the coating stick during frying."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering (350°F/175°C)."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"Fry milanesas one or two at a time—don't crowd the pan. Cook 2-3 minutes per side until golden brown and crispy."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"Preheat broiler. Place fried milanesas on a baking sheet."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Top each milanesa with a layer of tomato sauce, a slice of ham, and two slices of mozzarella."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":10,"text":"Sprinkle with oregano and Parmesan if using."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":11,"text":"Broil for 2-3 minutes until cheese is melted and bubbling with golden spots."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":12,"text":"Serve immediately with French fries (papas fritas) and a simple salad—this is the traditional Argentine way."}]}17:["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$1f"}}],"$L20","$L21","$L22","$L23"]}]

greasy."}]]}],["$","li","4",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The tomato sauce should be simple—just good canned tomatoes, garlic, and salt. Don't use heavy marinara."}]]}],["$","li","5",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Some Argentines add a slice of roasted red pepper under the cheese—delicious variation."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
34:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Milanesa arrived with Italian immigrants in the late 19th century, evolving from the Italian cotoletta alla milanese. The 'napolitana' variation—topped with tomato sauce, ham, and cheese—is distinctly Argentine and has no equivalent in Naples. It became popular in Buenos Aires' Italian neighborhoods and spread nationwide. Today, every Argentine family has their milanesa recipe, and it's the unofficial national comfort food."}]}]]}]
35:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Refrigerate cooked milanesas for up to 2 days. Reheat in a 375°F (190°C) oven for 10 minutes—not the microwave, which makes them soggy. Uncooked, breaded milanesas freeze well for 1 month—fry from frozen, adding 2 minutes."}]}]]}]
